content: The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 is cited as the constitutional authority to regulate commerce and make laws necessary for executing government powers. The Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998 amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. Penalties under Section 1028(b) are also amended to include offenses related to the transfer or use of identification. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties for identity theft offenses related to obtaining anything of value aggregating $1,000 or more in a year. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for offenses related to drug trafficking, crimes of violence, or repeat convictions. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code introduces forfeiture of personal property used in committing identity theft offenses. It also expands circumstances under which the offense applies to interstate or foreign commerce and transportation through mail. Definitions are updated to include terms related to document-making implements. Definitions are updated to include terms related to document-making implements, identification documents, and means of identification. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code includes definitions for terms like personal identification card, produce, and State. It also addresses attempt and conspiracy related to identity theft offenses. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims and means of identification involved in the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims, means of identification involved, value of loss, range of conduct, sentencing enhancements, statutory maximum penalties, achievement of sentencing purposes, and other relevant factors. The Federal Trade Commission will establish a centralized complaint and consumer education service for victims of identity theft. This service will log complaints, provide information to victims, and refer complaints to appropriate entities, including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this service. SEC. 6. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include a correction related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. SEC. 7. Redaction of ethics reports filed by judicial officers and employees. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by certain individuals if revealing personal information could endanger them. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must submit an annual report on the redacted reports and threats against individuals. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations on when redaction is appropriate for reports filed by individuals to protect against threats. This provision expires on December 31, 2001, and applies to filings through calendar year 2001.
